div.p: This next example shows a typical use of the cite element:
div.pre: My favourite book is The Reality Dysfunction by Peter F. Hamilton. My favourite comic is Pearls Before Swine by Stephan Pastis. My favourite track is Jive Samba by the Cannonball Adderley Sextet.
According to the Wikipedia article HTML, as it stood in mid-February 2008, leaving attribute values unquoted is unsafe. This is obviously an over-simplification.
div.p: The following, however, is incorrect usage, as the cite element here is containing far more than the title of the work:
div.pre: According to the Wikipedia article on HTML, as it stood in mid-February 2008, leaving attribute values unquoted is unsafe. This is obviously an over-simplification.]]>

div.p: The cite element is obviously a key part of any citation in a bibliography, but it is only used to mark the title:
div.pre: Universal Declaration of Human Rights, United Nations, December 1948. Adopted by General Assembly resolution 217 A (III).
